were beyond war. Oh yeah. Beyond war crimes. I don't know if you've heard the news today,
but as the Russians are pulling out of places and the, and the Ukrainians are pulling into
the moving into those places as the Russians, it seems like are kind of retreating. They're
finding mass graves, war crimes, people bound hand and foot shot, killed, like, there you
go. I mean, that's well, welcome to the human race. I don't, I don't get why that doesn't
cause people pause to go. Maybe this whole human trusting in humans thing is starting
to fall apart on me anyway. Um, and the other end of world significance when we left, Will
Smith was still one of the good guys. Right. He was still one of the nice guys. What's

Post it versus this is, this is why we, we know, or we believe that paper beats rock.
Yeah, that's good. There has been the meme started flying so fast. He just invented,
he created a meme out of himself in one moment. Um, but, um, another, uh, so I'll introduce
me very quickly and then mention another massive world shift. Um, but, uh, so it's
Chris leg and, uh, and I'm a pastor and a therapist and kind of a lot of what I do is
travel and speak when I'm available. But, and so that's why some of the topics we're
talking about the worldview topics and that kind of stuff. And you might've even noticed

when it comes to a lot of the apologetics, cause I just, when you work with students

And if you're not prepared to dig them up and to work for it, um, they, they smell right

And I've been doing that for a long time, actually for a while, um, used to travel and

and then come back and talk about it.
Chris Driver.
Chris Driver was the name of it. Yep. The name of the atheist skit character that my

I was like, can I speak before they introduce me? So, Brinn, introduce yourself. My name

Perfect. Right. So, but I want you to listen, Bryn isn't here because she's our token female

Anyway. But, but, and that crisis is that when we left last time, Chris shared was going to
still be on staff here at South spring forever. And that is no longer true. Yes. So yeah,
Chris, let's hear the story. Introduce yourself and tell us the story. And okay. My name is Chris
Jared still, and I'm still married. All the same kids. No, I think it's funny. I feel like
whenever people go on, how long have you been married? This summer will be 29 years. Okay.
We're right there with you. We're with 29. Okay. Yep. I just, when, well, okay. So I am going to
be starting soon within the next couple of months, a job at watermark community church in Dallas.
Yep. And we're actually very proud. Yes. Thank you. It'll be the marriage and family director is my
role there, but it's so funny cause you're on sabbatical and I'm always like, why does this
happen when people are in sabbatical? Either the person comes back and says, I've decided on
a reason. Like I feel like that happens or all this other stuff while you're gone. And so I
really was hesitating like, do I ruin, do I call him? I didn't know what to do, but I did call you
and it was well received. It was what Chris, like you're actually not allowed to do that. Right. Oh,
gosh. Oh, I think, I think your boss, John would light me on fire if it was, I mean, I actually
would, I don't want to risk his psychological health like that. Like I don't know the red
friend would survive it. So Colson can take a sabbatical for 15 years. That's right. But that's
exciting. And of course the hope is that you'll still be able to do the podcast. I really do. If
we can figure the technology. Yeah. Yeah. So that wasn't at me and I'm like, yes. Hologram. Yeah.
Exactly. There you go. Holograms, zoom, Skype. We can figure that out. Surely something will work,
but that was what made us start thinking who on staff would be the right person to step in if
Chris had to go. And was that choice. And, uh, and is just like giving us a thumbs up.
I've been waiting for the call. She's like, finally, it's so humbling. I've like learned
from Chris and Chris have been Chris squared, as we call them are just two of the people that
I admire most. And my husband and I have learned from seeing just so much in our marriage and life.
And so that's super humbling. The three of us worked at the same camp. We all worked for
Panko, but you guys both met your spouses. It's taking credit for us meeting. That's right. But
honestly, I mean, with his premarital counseling, like there you go. Thanks to the sheriffs and the
Lord. Very good. That's good. Yup. That's exciting. So anyway, that's if we didn't,
and that was not a great introduction either, which is fine. You can stalk us if it's worth it
to you. You can, you can check out the South spring website. That is one way to do that.
Staff bio pages, at least for the time being, all four of us will be on there. That's true.
And then you can go to the watermark website. That's exactly right. And you never know,
maybe we'll have a reconstructed faith website. That's exactly. Ooh. Hey, yeah. Whoa. That's okay.
Okay. So where we left off, our last one, our last episode was kind of the conclusion of the
David Smalley interview and then kind of you guys commenting on that. And then right before this,
Chris Sherrod had mentioned just something that has been rattling around in your brain
regarding some of those conversations that you had. And so you want to share that because you had
some good insight and a really cool analogy that you shared. I think that'd be valuable.
Yeah. Well, as I, as I was listening to the interviews with David and I told Chris, I don't
know what his church upbringing was. It sounded like it wasn't a very welcoming environment for
questions like, like we have here, but it seems like he was many times making, going pretty far
to make the point that people aren't that bad. Like there are bad people, but there've been a
lot of people doing really, really good stuff. And then he, um, early on had said something like,
why can't God just let us into heaven? And my response was more like, I'm, I'm more like,
I can't believe we're getting led into heaven. Like that's amazing type thing. And I think
where we were missing was his view of man is that we're not that bad. And the analogy that he gave,
was from some other atheist guy who during his presentation would always pretend to miss a slide
and then kind of act like he's fumbling around like, Oh, I'm sorry, guys. I missed that. We
forgive me. And he's like, no, really we, we forgive me. And then his point was, why can't
God just do that? You guys just did that. Why can't God just do that? So that was going around
in my mind. And then I saw another meme of Jesus knocking at the door, the classic one, and he's
saying like, please let me in. And the person's like, why? And he says, because of what I'll do
to you if you don't let me in. And so I really think there's this misunderstanding of our modern
mind can easily grasp the love of God that there's a loving God out there, but the, the
holiness and justice and even wrath of God is really foreign to us. I think ancient minds would
probably more resonate with that. And this concept of God loving us like a father was,
was revolutionary for them. So I think we really wrestle with that. And the fact is the Bible
teaches both of those that God is, I'm incredibly loving and gracious and merciful, but he's also
holy and he's just. And if you, if you lose that part of his character, there's all these facets
of who God is. If you, if you drop that, your sin really doesn't seem that bad because comparatively,
if I'm looking horizontally to other people, it's easy to go on. I mean, I might not be perfect,
but I'm no Hitler or Stalin or whatever. So I just think that that's a big part of what's going on
in his mind there that it doesn't seem that bad. It seems petty. Why can't God, these are rules he
made up anyways. Why can't he just, you know, pardon the rules. So I think a misunderstanding
that God's moral standard flows from him, not just made up by him. It's not like he can just arbitrarily
decide, but the analogy that I read, reread recently in the transforming power of the gospel
by Jerry Bridges is so good. He basically says this, if you had a rug in your house, just to cover up
a spot in your living room on the floor that you bought at a thrift store and I'm in there and I
spill ink on it, I've ruined your $100 rug, maybe if you paid that much for it, which is a bummer.
But if you had like a $300,000 Persian rug and I spill ink on it, totally different response. It's
not like, yeah, why can't you just forgive me? It's like, I am so sorry. Oh my goodness. And the thing
is it's the same ink. It's the worth of the rug that it was spilled on that changes your response
and how big of a deal it is. And his point is that's the way it is with God. That when we see
who God is and how amazingly holy and awesome and majestic, you've got all these words in scripture
about him, then you realize the spilling of the ink. In fact, if we're going to talk about how
bad we are, I poured the ink out. I didn't just, oops, it was an accident. Like I made a mistake.
That's what people say nowadays. Like my adultery was a mistake. I do admit that. It's like,
you know what I mean? It just sounds like, oops. Oh, that's the immediate thought I had when the
first time I heard that the guy on the, oh, I did the slides wrong. Would you forgive me? Yeah. Like,
sure. Well, what that just communicates is I either don't have very high requirements for
your slideshow. Right. Sure. Now, if I paid you a million dollars a slide, right? I might go,
I mean, you'll owe me a million bucks. Right. So I mean, like, yeah, I'm not, I am forgiving you,
but there's a debt you have to pay me for it. Or I don't value my time. I mean, if I was an
attorney making a thousand dollars a minute and you fumbled through a slide for 10 minutes or two
minutes or five minutes, I might go, I mean, yeah, my time is worth this much. So what, what the
person has done is created a straw man argument where there's just a minute, a very, very, very,
very, very minimal cost. So the question would be, okay, so what if I slit your wife's throat over
your Persian rug? And then it's like, okay, will y'all forgive me? No, really. Will you forgive me?
Okay, great. That's easy. See, see, why can't you just forgive me? Right. So one is we're equating
the, we're making it a non-crime and then asking for forgiveness against a non-crime against an
unimportant person, a meaningless person. So yeah, a non-crime against a meaningless person is not,
may not even need any forgiveness. So it isn't, it isn't equality. It isn't a good analogy,
in my opinion. It's a very flawed analogy to say the depth of the crime matters. In fact,
I've always said it would be really hard for me to respect somebody who didn't really, really hate
the Holocaust. Yeah. Like who do think like, no, just forget it. You know what? Right. Even
Steven, everybody makes mistakes. Yeah. You Hitler guy, all you Nazis, it's, it's fine. Really,
it's fine. And I think we would all go, I'm not sure that that's a morally good person who doesn't
take that seriously. So my thought was, and I think Martin Lloyd-Jones makes some kind of analogy
like this too. This old analogy, but if I was in your house and you weren't there and I happened
to see a bill that you owed and I told you like, Hey, I paid for that bill. How would you respond?
You'd be like, well, it depends on the bill. If this is like, yeah, it's like my toll fee for three
bucks. You'd be like, wow, thanks. That was cool. But it was like the IRS for like seven years back
taxes, like I'm threatened with jail and you paid it. Then I'm like, no way. So I just think the depth
of how you view God. Jesus should have said something like that. The person who's forgiven
much. Yes. So last, last thing was CS Lewis. I really like in, um, and I think it's a problem
of pain, but where he says we want in fact, not so much a father in heaven as a grandfather in
heaven, a senile benevolence who as they say, liked to see young people enjoying themselves
and whose plan for the universe was simply that it might be truly said at the end of each day,
a good time was had by all like that. Instead of well done, my good and faithful servant.
We really want that God who's really not that serious about our holiness or, um, you know,
it's just, and as a granddad, now I get it. Like I really look at my, I just want my grandkids to
like me. Yeah. With my kids. I'm like, I don't care if you like me, this is what you're going to do.
Exactly. Are you happy with me? It's weird. I've heard that, but you don't really do you feel that
what's your grandpa name? Pops pops. Don't you want to come back and see pops? Right. Don't you
want to come back and spend more time with pops? Nice. Pops is nicer than your dad. Yep.
Well, thank you for sharing that. Cause I think that's a, that's a really good insight. Um,
was Chris, was there anything that kind of stuck out from, from you or what were you going to say?
Yeah. If you had brain, what are you going to, Oh yeah. I was just going to ask, don't you think
that some of that is just back, speaks to our depravity again, because it's us turning to look
at ourselves. And so we're comparing it's like a humanist thought of, um, I'm turning and looking
at myself and compared to what I see around me and what I want and what I want God to be like,
instead of turning and looking at God. And so we're focused on ourselves and we're rating
ourselves on our own standards. And instead it's like often when we don't think our sin is,
is severe, we don't understand the depth of it. It's because we're looking at ourselves and not at
Jesus. Yeah. That's a good point. I heard a guy, a guy at camp one time had a great analogy of,
um, the old chasm with God on one side of man on the other. And Jesus is the bridge.
And he just was talking about as he's gotten older and saw his own depravity, but really saw who God
really is, he feels that chasm getting bigger and bigger. Like, Oh my goodness. It is so,
which means his Jesus gets bigger. Like what Jesus did gets even bigger. And I really think that's
Paul as he got older, you know, I'm the least of the apostles, least of the saints, chief of, chief
of sinners. And a lot of Christians, I think even with deconstruction might sometimes feel discouraged.
Like I'm just so bad. I'm more and more aware of my sinfulness, which is, could be a good thing.
It's not that you're sending more necessarily. You're just more aware of your sin that you didn't
see before, but I just, yeah, it's gonna, it's gonna go back to seeing who God is.
Okay. I've also got a comment on just the nature of reality with this. So as a, as a counselor,
as a psychologist, a therapist, this is like one of the things I've learned over time is the stance,
the reality is that all debts are paid. Like this is just, it's just a thing. I mean, it's just,
it is the nature of freedom. If there's such a thing as freedom, then there's going to be such
a thing as debt and there's such a thing, a debt, all debts have to be paid somehow. Like to say,
I forgive you when those guys, you know, if you, if I forgive the guy fumbling through his slides,
skipping a slide, what I've said is yes, I will just eat those 10 seconds of mine you wasted,
but someone has to pay for those 10 seconds. I'm just agreeing that I'll be the one who pays them.
Sure. Fine. I forgive you. I'll pay them. And so obviously that's when the amount of debt is
significant. If, if you say, yeah, I'll forgive that. I'm happy to forgive that I'm willing to
forgive that I'm whatever is because the amount of debt really does matter. And so in this
situation, all debts have to be somehow paid for. And if there are debts, I can't afford to pay.
Then in this cosmic universe, it seems like it's someone has to pay them and it's got to be taken
care of. It either needs to be me or someone else is going to have to pay it. It just,
and then the more therapy I do in an area heading of forgiveness, the more I realize
I have to either say, I will accept this payment. So yeah, I was richly abused as a child for years
and years and years. If someone says that, and then you go, okay, so let's work through forgiving
that it, it doesn't mean that that pain just vanishes. It doesn't mean, you know, that the
other person doesn't have still have something that they ought to be trying to, it just means
you're saying I'm going to live life with this debt that it's going to go unpaid except by me.
I'm just going to absorb this as a reality in my life. And, and, but how can anyone afford to do
that? That's the question is how could anyone afford, how could I afford to take on a debt
like that to go, okay, I'm going to take on this debt. No one else is going to pay it. I will take
it on. Well, the reason I can afford to take on that debt is the parable Jesus tells of the guy
who is forgiven. I think it's 10,000 talents. A talent is 20 years of work. And so it's like
200,000 days of work or some 200,000 years of work pay that, that this guy forgives. So it's,
it's, it's meant to be ludicrous when the guy says, oh no, but just give me more time. I'll pay it.
Like, no, you're not. It's not possible to pay this debt. And then the guy goes and another guy
owes him. So he's forgiven this 200,000 year debt. And, and then he goes to another guy who,
who owes him real debt. By the way, I love the fact that Jesus doesn't make it two bucks. It is,
it is a month's wages. And so the audio of me, you know, if I owe Chris shared a month's wages,
I mean, that's not a small amount. So I mean, it's going to be hard to pay that. And so to say,
how do I pay that it's going to, I'm going to, I'm going to change my life somehow. I'm going to
make adaptations, go to change things, went to figure this out, to pay him back,
um, to pay back a month's wages. But, but the point Jesus makes here is no, no,
I just forgave you your monthly payments on 200,000 years. So, you know, you, you were paying me
a million dollars a month. Chris, Chris owes you a thousand dollars a month. You can forgive his
debt and still come out $999,000 a head every month. That's the whole concept of forgiveness
that God gives. I'll take it on. And then you can now afford to forgive other people because
I've removed such a massive debt from you. And anyway, that's, I am struck by, I think just a
denial of reality to go, forget about it. No one has to pay for the Holocaust. No one has to pay
for the shoplifting. Did y'all forget that speech as a, maybe you didn't from your dad's as a kid,
like what difference does it make if somebody steals a candy bar from Walmart? Right? I mean,
it's what would they come out behind 30 cents. They do, they do 10 million a day, just at
probably to hear and Tyler like, man, what difference does it make? He's like, and my dad
starts explaining, you know, this, well, what if you have everybody doing that and then you have,
it's happening all over and then you have to pay people for security and then you have to do,
and before long, that candy bar, which would have been 50 cents, just cost you 75 cents,
or instead of a dollar, it costs a dollar 50 and it costs everybody that. So all these little sins
pile up and creep out and someone's got to pay them. And you go, well, Walmart can afford to pay
50 cents. Right? The problem is can Walmart afford to pay, you know, 50 million dollars a year in
shoplifting expenses? No, not without charging you. And so anyway, just everything gets paid.
The book of Hebrews says without the shedding of blood, there's no remission of sins.
Everybody pay, something, it's something pays for everything. So anyway.
And I think David got caught up on that too with blood and stuff. And I think he did,
the seriousness of it is this animal's dying in the place of you should be dying. Like there's
that concept of if you're just making a sacrifice, but it's a reminder of life is being taken here.
Right. So it's not archaic and pagan and ancient. It's like, no, this is a reminder, you know, and
that's, it was all leading up to Jesus paying for it. But I think the other side of this still is
to remind people to not wallow in, you're right. I am such a terrible person. God is so holy.
Cause that's that phrase. We're more lost and sinful than we ever did imagine, but we're more
loved and accepted in Christ and we ever did believe or hope. Right. Like that's the other good,
that's the good reminder of the gospel that Chris has so many of those. You are now, I didn't make
that up though, but you are, yes, terrible, but don't give up hope. Some people need to be humbled
out of their pride. Like you are bad. Some of them need to be affirmed out of, but don't despair.
And I do think it goes back to the character of God that I think when it clicked for me that I
want a God that's just because of what that says about him, like God is loving. And all of us,
you talked about this of how we all have this in us. Kids have this where if my friend gets hit
on the playground, we have, we want that person to pay. And I think everyone gets that concept
when you break it down to everyday interactions. But then when we turn and look at God,
we somehow change his justice into an evil characteristic. And it's like, no, this,
we want a God that's just because it speaks to his holiness and his lovingness. If we
had a God that was like, eh, I wouldn't want to serve that God, you know? And so that's comforting,
but it often gets flipped on its head to mean the exact opposite of his character.
Wow. And his forgiveness is not a commendation or affirmation of your character, but a reflection
of his character. Like it's because he's so amazing. Not because you're so great.
Yep. That's a, those are some good insights. And we've come back over and over again to the
lack of that intuitive, that early. So for those of you who are parents out there,
realizing that early influence of moms and dads who are safe, who are gentle, who are strong,
it helps kids move forward in a correct understanding of who God is. And it always,
when I think of a God who isn't just, or God who isn't even wrathful, I just think about what a
poor father that would be. That, that I remember so distinctly talking through with my 11 year old
daughter, when her OCD began to set in some on the whole idea of, I'm afraid somebody's going to
kidnap me. And the conversation she then wanted to have with me was for her to get a grip of how
deadly her dad is. Like, dad, how would you protect me? Could you, do you know how to protect me?
What would you do? And, and that's not the, I would never want her to think that's my only
character trait, right? Cause I don't want her to be afraid to tell me later in life with something
that happens to her. Cause she's afraid of, well, that I'll be a loose cannon, but she does want
me to be just and powerful. And that was super important to her. And I remember that and thinking,
I need a, I need a God. And, and because I had a good dad, I think that's intuitively easier for
me to understand the idea of a God who is, who is absolutely, you know, the, the power that he has
that he could bring to bear if he chose to is without limit. But he, that power exists for my
behalf since I am in his child, since he's adopted me to his child. Now I am the, I received the
discipline from him, but not the wrath from him, but I still want him to be wrathful about evil.
Which is why C is loose is so genius to make aslin a lion. Yep. It's just so brilliant. Cause
no, he's not safe. He's a lion, but he's good. Good stuff.
Yeah. Well, it's awesome. Well, Hey, I am so glad that we've gotten back in the studio.
Welcome to the team. I feel like I'm just here to learn and ask questions.
Join the club. Join the club. Well, that's great. We'll be back soon with, with even more episodes.
Thanks for listening. Thank you for joining us for this episode of reconstructed faith.
If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review.
It'll help other people find us. If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear
discussed, shoot me an email at info at southspring.org. Reconstructed faith is a resource
of South spring Baptist church. Remember don't give up trust. God search for answers.
